titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jane LaTour Papers WAG.317
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-01-21 16:04:06 -0500.

change.item: Updated by Craig Savino to include materials added from accessions 2016.036 and 2016.037
Updated by Amy C. Vo to include materials from the 2019 accretion

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 12 record cartons and 4 manuscript boxes.

did.abstract: Jane LaTour is a journalist, labor activist, and educator living in New York City. She has written for various union publications, managed the Women's Project of the Association for Union Democracy, and wrote the book Sisters in the Brotherhoods: Working Women Organizing for Equality in New York City. She is a two-time winner of the Mary Heaton Vorse Award, the top labor journalism award in New York City. This collection consists of materials created or collected in the course of writing Sisters in the Brotherhoods, and include correspondence with interview subjects, research files, oral history interview transcripts, and manuscripts drafts focused on women in the labor movement, focusing on blue-collar and trade employment. Topics that recur throughout these materials include discimination, welfare, vocational education, and pregnancy as it pertains to working women.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of Jane LaTour consist of materials created and collected by LaTour in the course of researching, writing, and discussing her book Sisters in the Brotherhoods. Materials include correspondence with interview subjects, research files, oral history interview transcripts, and manuscripts drafts focused on women in the labor movement, focusing on blue-collar and trade employment. Topics that recur throughout these materials include discimination, welfare, vocational education, and pregnancy as it pertains to working women.

The 2019 accretion includes correspondence correspondence and research files regarding the #MeToo movement, sexual harassment, sex discrimination in the workplace, gender equality, and women in labor unions. There are materials such as correspondence and publicity from after the release of Jane LaTour's book, Sisters in the Brotherhoods: Working Women Organizing for Equality in New York City, as well as the initial proposal for the book.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jane LaTouris a journalist, labor activist, and educator living in New York City. She has written for various union publications, managed the Women's Project of the Association for Union Democracy, and wrote the book Sisters in the Brotherhoods: Working Women Organizing for Equality in New York City. She is a two-time winner of the Mary Heaton Vorse Award, the top labor journalism award in New York City.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Jane LaTour was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

The donor has agreed to give the Tamiment Library non-exclusive worldwide online and print publication rights in perpetuity for non-commercial use of the collection. Any images from the collection that are published must be accompanied by the following credit line: "Image from the Jane LaTour Papers."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Jane LaTour in several installments between 2000-2016. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 1950.189, 2011.012, 2016.036, NPA.2000.132, and 2019.119.
Provenance unknown for materials found in the repository that were added to the collection in 2014. The accession number associated with these materials is 2014.060.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Jane LaTour Papers; WAG 317; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Photographs were separated from this collection during initial processing and were established as a separate collection, the Jane LaTour Photographs (PHOTOS 147). In 2014, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the Jane LaTour Papers (WAG 317).
Materials found in the repository in 2014 were added to Box 7.
Materials in the 2019 accretion were rehoused in new acid-free folders where necessary, with original titles transcribed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials created and collected by LaTour in the course of researching, writing, and discussing her book Sisters in the Brotherhoods. Materials include correspondence with interview subjects, research files, oral history interview transcripts, and manuscripts drafts focused on women in the labor movement, focusing on blue-collar and trade employment. Topics that recur throughout these materials include discimination, welfare, vocational education, and pregnancy as it pertains to working women.
